snippet.textDisplay:
NOTE: some misinformed people are recommending i call the video “people with autism” to be more respectful but i reached out to the autistic community and “autistic people” is heavily preferred. please listen to the community before spreading potentially incorrect* information.
ORIGINAL POST: come back next week for I spent a day with 911 EMERGENCY DISPATCHERS -- thank you so much for supporting me and this series :)
luv, anthony padildo
ps: shoutout to everyone who has turned on notifications 🔔 and directly support me in continuing this series.
snippet.textOriginal:
NOTE: some misinformed people are recommending i call the video “people with autism” to be more respectful but i reached out to the autistic community and “autistic people” is heavily preferred. please listen to the community before spreading potentially incorrect* information.
ORIGINAL POST: come back next week for *I spent a day with 911 EMERGENCY DISPATCHERS* -- thank you so much for supporting me and this series :)
luv, anthony padildo
ps: shoutout to everyone who has turned on notifications 🔔 and directly support me in continuing this series.

snippet.textDisplay: As an autistic person, I have watched SO many videos about autism made by allistic people, and this is one of the most thoughtful and respectful that I have ever seen. You have genuinely allowed your guests to speak for themselves, and your commentary shows that you’ve researched the topic and truly paid attention to how the community would (generally) like to be represented. Sure, not everyone is high functioning, and that was not part of the video - but I personally feel that the media heavily over-represents the “tragedy” of autism, and the adult experience is often tossed aside. Kudos to Anthony and the rest of your production team - I was already intrigued by this series, but now I’m extra excited because I feel like I can look forward to lots of kind, attentive, non-stigmatizing interviews with unique and/or misunderstood groups. Yay!
snippet.textOriginal: As an autistic person, I have watched SO many videos about autism made by allistic people, and this is one of the most thoughtful and respectful that I have ever seen. You have genuinely allowed your guests to speak for themselves, and your commentary shows that you’ve researched the topic and truly paid attention to how the community would (generally) like to be represented. Sure, not everyone is high functioning, and that was not part of the video - but I personally feel that the media heavily over-represents the “tragedy” of autism, and the adult experience is often tossed aside. Kudos to Anthony and the rest of your production team - I was already intrigued by this series, but now I’m extra excited because I feel like I can look forward to lots of kind, attentive, non-stigmatizing interviews with unique and/or misunderstood groups. Yay!

snippet.textDisplay: Everyone in my family has some kind of disorder. My mom has adhd, my dad has asperger's, my oldest brother has austim spectrum, my sister has adhd and autism, and my other brother has adhd, anxiety disorder, ptsd, and autism. He is doing very bad. He's 27 now and still lives at home, and there are people 'helping' him find a place for his own (with 24/7 contact in case he needs help) but nothing's been happening over the past months. He had several psychoses, sometimes lasting for multiple days, and that even resulted in him being stuck at a crisis instance for a few days. He's on biological medication now, which semi-helps, but he still breaks stuff, moves things around, and screams or suddenly runs away, purely out of compulsion. He picks up absolutely no social signs so he can't understand if we are tired or want to be left alone, and even the slightest sounds trigger him extemely, alot of times into a panic/anger attack. It's really difficult living with him. But he's a sweetheart deep inside. He'll suddenly come surprise you with a gift or a cup or tea, and always loves to help.
snippet.textOriginal: Everyone in my family has some kind of disorder. My mom has adhd, my dad has asperger's, my oldest brother has austim spectrum, my sister has adhd and autism, and my other brother has adhd, anxiety disorder, ptsd, and autism. He is doing very bad. He's 27 now and still lives at home, and there are people 'helping' him find a place for his own (with 24/7 contact in case he needs help) but nothing's been happening over the past months. He had several psychoses, sometimes lasting for multiple days, and that even resulted in him being stuck at a crisis instance for a few days. He's on biological medication now, which semi-helps, but he still breaks stuff, moves things around, and screams or suddenly runs away, purely out of compulsion. He picks up absolutely no social signs so he can't understand if we are tired or want to be left alone, and even the slightest sounds trigger him extemely, alot of times into a panic/anger attack. It's really difficult living with him. But he's a sweetheart deep inside. He'll suddenly come surprise you with a gift or a cup or tea, and always loves to help.

snippet.textDisplay: I really appreciate that 2 out of the 3 people you interviewed were girls, because autism in girls is considerably less diagnosed than in boys because we often present differently and a lot of the studies and information available on autism is based on boys behaviour and studies on boys. This video almost made me cry and I am so glad you're doing this amazing series that is educating people in a positive and informative way. It feels good to be recognised and represented <3
snippet.textOriginal: I really appreciate that 2 out of the 3 people you interviewed were girls, because autism in girls is considerably less diagnosed than in boys because we often present differently and a lot of the studies and information available on autism is based on boys behaviour and studies on boys. This video almost made me cry and I am so glad you're doing this amazing series that is educating people in a positive and informative way. It feels good to be recognised and represented <3

snippet.textDisplay: Autism is so misunderstood... I appreciate these interviews so much bc if the public was more informed about what it means to be autistic (instead of all the fear-mongering with the anti-vax crusaders) they might consider how seeing the world differently could provide great contributions to society, if  those who do, were treated in a way that allows their confidence to grow. Temple Grandin’s TED talk on the subject is amazing too!! Very inspiring and enlightening learning about her experience.
snippet.textOriginal: Autism is so misunderstood... I appreciate these interviews so much bc if the public was more informed about what it means to be autistic (instead of all the fear-mongering with the anti-vax crusaders) they might consider how seeing the world differently could provide great contributions to society, if  those who do, were treated in a way that allows their confidence to grow. Temple Grandin’s TED talk on the subject is amazing too!! Very inspiring and enlightening learning about her experience.

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you for making this Anthony. I have adhd and there are very strong similarities between the two. For me, I also struggle with eye contact, emotional regulation, racing thoughts, panic attacks and sensory issues like sound. I love how you treated these lovely people so nicely- not patronising or pitying or rudely, just how you talk to everyone else, casual and funny and friendly. The more people like you share info like this the more we are accepted and accept ourselves, thank you once again x
snippet.textOriginal: Thank you for making this Anthony. I have adhd and there are very strong similarities between the two. For me, I also struggle with eye contact, emotional regulation, racing thoughts, panic attacks and sensory issues like sound. I love how you treated these lovely people so nicely- not patronising or pitying or rudely, just how you talk to everyone else, casual and funny and friendly. The more people like you share info like this the more we are accepted and accept ourselves, thank you once again x

snippet.textDisplay: I note the pinned comment, yet still, in general it is encouraged to "put the people first" as in start your description with the fact that they are people so yes "people with ..." Is in general the more respected description. I applaud your reaching out to the community but for people reading these comments without the outreach Anthony has and who cannot ask a whole community please always try to put people first
snippet.textOriginal: I note the pinned comment, yet still, in general it is *encouraged* to "put the people first" as in start your description with the fact that they are people so yes "people with ..." Is *in general* the more respected description. I applaud your reaching out to the community but for people reading these comments without the outreach Anthony has and who cannot ask a whole community please always try to put people first

snippet.textDisplay: So I have a mild case of autism but with fairly bad sensory issues. Eg: always getting picked put by teachers for not paying attention to the sounds that are important which would be their voice. But also with my autism, I've been able to acquire the ability to draw really well, I do photorealism with charcoal etc. To me it's always about understanding how to do it, and the determination to finish the project. I've also trained myself to act and talk like people that dont have autism.
snippet.textOriginal: So I have a mild case of autism but with fairly bad sensory issues. Eg: always getting picked put by teachers for not paying attention to the sounds that are important which would be their voice. But also with my autism, I've been able to acquire the ability to draw really well, I do photorealism with charcoal etc. To me it's always about understanding how to do it, and the determination to finish the project. I've also trained myself to act and talk like people that dont have autism.

snippet.textDisplay: i will go off on people who say "they are called people with autism". Autistics are very literal in their speech, and there is no literal difference between autistic person and a person with autism. And funny that this mostly comes from non-autistic individuals, i have never meet a fellow autistic that cares if you call them an autistic person. If you think it matter, you must not know much about autism and how we think
snippet.textOriginal: i will go off on people who say "they are called people with autism". Autistics are very literal in their speech, and there is no literal difference between autistic person and a person with autism. If you think it matter, you must not know much about autism and how we think

snippet.textDisplay: I have CAPD. It took me till i was 19 to accept the fact i was on the spectrum. As a kid i had anger issues. Teenager my frustration with not understanding lectures and i couldn't fuckin hear shit. Like yes the teacher spoke English. Shit i did to,but i could NOT  understand them. The frustration turned into depression (plus telling my mother what had happened to me when i was 8)  it was just alot man. But what Really made me have to accept myself. Was when i started working. Turns out i cant work at subway or waitressing cuz i find that people sound like their under water and im trying to figure out what there saying. Its rough being a kid man. But honestly i like the way i turned out. Even if i stil got some hurdles to go through. Its okay man.
snippet.textOriginal: I have CAPD. It took me till i was 19 to accept the fact i was on the spectrum. As a kid i had anger issues. snippet.textOriginal: My sister was diagnosed with autism and stoped talking. We found out it was because of the vaccinations we got her. We still get vaccinations but one at a time. My sister got better and learned to speak again.

snippet.textDisplay:
Honestly i can relate to Jasmine i was diagnosed with Autism at 11 my mum was devastated but my dad well he doesn't live with us but he doesn't believe i have Autism which lowers my thoughts on him with school i was worried people would make fun of me but no-one really did and I've been hiding emotions for some time at this point i don't know how it works but along with school still i wanted to know how a relationship works but i fail to get one but i am really interested upon art i mainly draw anime and Transformers but still i can sorta relate with Jasmine
Also that teacher i believe i had a teacher who wanted my life to be hell but i carried on no matter what. Still i personally think there shouldn't be a cure for Autism because like Dr Seuss
"why fit in when you were born to stand out"

snippet.textDisplay: Please do an episode about people with ADHD! As an ADHDer that wasn’t diagnosed until much later in life, I feel like my disorder is incredibly misunderstood. I went undiagnosed until 20 years old because people seem to think only little boys who having a hard time sitting still have ADHD. It’s a truly complex disorder that affects almost all aspects of my life, and I really wish more people would talk about it. Love this series Anthony!!

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm on the spectrum. I'm fine with social cues, but I have pretty bad sensory issues. I can't wear leggings cause they feel to soft, if to many people are talking at once my brain turns to mush, really big rooms make me uncomfortable, when I'm scared I need to feel a wall against my back to help ground myself, and some other stuffs.

It's very strange how such spacific things affect people differently

snippet.textDisplay: I work with children with autism, they are some of the most brilliant and loving children I have ever met. Thank you for this video, autism is not a disease, and it doesn’t need to be cured. Everyone is different, Thank you for highlighting they’re differences in a respectful way. These three individuals should be so proud, they bravely shared their stories. ❤️ your channel is a gift Anthony.

snippet.textDisplay: I'm not sure if I'm on the spectrum or not (it could be ADHD but I don't have $2000 to just spend on a test) but I definitely have sensory overload a lot, which can feel like a panic attack, but it's more of a meltdown where I can't control myself. One of the main things is actually those bars that you have to walk though going in and out of libraries, because they make this really high pitched sound that not very many people can hear. Also, certain fabrics and clothing styles bother me, and food textures also. I used to hate avocado because it's so slimy, but then I tried it in sushi, and as a salad dressing because I was told avocados are healthy. The important thing is listen to your body, and to your friends. And always carry a stim/fidget toy and headphones. I don't leave the house without my Power Beats since they're noise isolating and don't have annoying cords.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm not sure if I'm on the spectrum or not (it could be ADHD but I don't have $2000 to just spend on a test) but I definitely have sensory overload a lot, which can feel like a panic attack, but it's more of a meltdown where I can't control myself. One of the main things is actually those bars that you have to walk though going in and out of libraries, because they make this really high pitched sound that not very many people can hear. Also, certain fabrics and clothing styles bother me, and food textures also. I used to hate avocado because it's so slimy, but then I tried it in sushi, and as a salad dressing because I was told avocados are healthy. The important thing is listen to your body, and to your friends. And always carry a stim/fidget toy and headphones. I don't leave the house without my Power Beats since they're noise isolating and don't have annoying cords.

snippet.textDisplay: I take Autism to the heart because my little siblings are autistic. It’s so sad how people automatically judge people with autism. There’s many forms of it and many people look at it as not being able to talk, throwing fits, having difficulty walking, being built different, etc. Autism is so much more than that. There’s people you’d never guess are Autistic. Just because people don’t fit the ‘stereotype’ of an Autistic person, it doesn’t mean they aren’t. People need to see that anybody with Autism is just as good as any other person. Nobody is normal or perfect. Everyone is different in their own ways. People with Autism can do just as much as anyone else can. People have to just see and believe. 🙌🏼🥰
snippet.textOriginal: I take Autism to the heart because my little siblings are autistic. It’s so sad how people automatically judge people with autism. There’s many forms of it and many people look at it as not being able to talk, throwing fits, having difficulty walking, being built different, etc. Autism is so much more than that. There’s people you’d never guess are Autistic. Just because people don’t fit the ‘stereotype’ of an Autistic person, it doesn’t mean they aren’t. People need to see that anybody with Autism is just as good as any other person. Nobody is normal or perfect. Everyone is different in their own ways. People with Autism can do just as much as anyone else can. People have to just see and believe. 🙌🏼🥰

snippet.textDisplay: You know what I think is even more upsetting than the lie that autism is caused by vaccines, is that those fear mongerers make autism sound as if it's the worst possible thing your child could be afflicted with (not cancer or a terminal disease), when there are so many functional people who have some form of autism and it's so different for each and every person.
snippet.textOriginal: You know what I think is even more upsetting than the lie that autism is caused by vaccines, is that those fear mongerers make autism sound as if it's the worst possible thing your child could be afflicted with (not cancer or a terminal disease), when there are so many functional people who have some form of autism and it's so different for each and every person.

snippet.textDisplay: I work with several people on the autism spectrum, they are just amazing people. Who just might need a few minutes alone at breaktime, or something similar. I also have an acquaintance who has Asperger syndrome, she's pretty "normal" most of the time, but can get a bit loud at discussions and not quite understand what's okay to say and not. But i don't blame her for that, we just try to explain why the thing she said wasn't okay.
snippet.textOriginal: I work with several people on the autism spectrum, they are just amazing people. Who just might need a few minutes alone at breaktime, or something similar. I also have an acquaintance who has Asperger syndrome, she's pretty "normal" most of the time, but can get a bit loud at discussions and not quite understand what's okay to say and not. But i don't blame her for that, we just try to explain why the thing she said wasn't okay.

snippet.textDisplay: I just recently found out I might be on the spectrum. Growing up my family didn't believe in mental illness, and it was difficult for me as a child to interact with other people. I thought there was something wrong with me and that I was just strange. Watching this, I realize that there are people who are just like me and that there is nothing wrong with me, I'm just a little different than the immediate people around me. Thank you for spreading awareness and speaking about things that not many want to

snippet.textDisplay:
Sensory overload is the biggest issue by far.

Sure there’s social problems like eye contact, misreading social cues, and not being able to automatically understand jokes as jokes.

I grew up abused and neglected becouse my parents didn’t understand why I acted different from my siblings.

Shocking absolutely nobody, I grew up scared of people and used to completely withdraw from others. I’m 21 and I still have mental breakdowns when I feel targeted.

I know it’s irrational and I understand my behaviors abnormal but nothing in my power can correct it. Mental therapy, further educating, speech therapy, and medication have no impact on my issues.

It really sucks to have daily migraines, uncontrollable thoughts, and the fear of making a mockery of myself.

(Such as the rather annoying example of how I always turn every sentence into an opinion instead of putting out there an actually interesting question or two.)
snippet.textOriginal:
Sensory overload is the biggest issue by far.

Sure there’s social problems like eye contact, misreading social cues, and not being able to automatically understand jokes as jokes.

I grew up abused and neglected becouse my parents didn’t understand why I acted different from my siblings. 

Shocking absolutely nobody, I grew up scared of people and used to completely withdraw from others. I’m 21 and I still have mental breakdowns when I feel targeted.

I know it’s irrational and I understand my behaviors abnormal but nothing in my power can correct it. Mental therapy, further educating, speech therapy, and medication have no impact on my issues.

It really sucks to have daily migraines, uncontrollable thoughts, and the fear of making a mockery of myself. 

(Such as the rather annoying example of how I always turn every sentence into an opinion instead of putting out there an actually interesting question or two.)

snippet.textDisplay:
I know that I have this negative opinion about autism, and I don't like it, and I get upset with myself knowing that I have this negative opinion
I know it stems from my cousin who has very severe autism, and is the only person I've ever met that has this. I know it stems from growing up and seeing my cousin, who is 15 years older than me, who is still acting as if he is 2 or 3 years old, despite being in his 40's now
